Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 10:01AM - edited Apr 4, 2010 10:04AM by kaye45 It sound like the doctor is being abundantly cautious. I had a lump removed some years ago, size of a marble and rock solid so it could not be aspirated. Scary stuff but it turned out to be nothing. Most of these things are so your chances of good news is high. Still had to spend 3 days in hospital with a drain, etc, but pain was pretty minimal. You have all the bases covered as far as help so do what my nurse told me after my mastectomy, "don't lift anything heavier than the remote control". You may want to sleep sitting up for a while to reduce local swelling.

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2010 05:31PM kaye45 wrote: I had the SNB the day before my mastectomy and all they used was a local anesthetic. It was not the worst thing I've been through in this BC journey - that would be being told I needed a mastectomy rather than a lumpectomy - but it was worth it because they only needed to remove 5 lymph nodes during surgery and that saved me problems with lymphodema later. I focussed on a spot on the ceiling and did deep breathing through the procedure and the time flew by. The anxiety is worse than the pain, honestly.
